newsitem.title: UK: New UK government raises interest rates to 6.25 pct.
newsitem.headline: New UK government raises interest rates to 6.25 pct.

text.p: Britain's new Labour government, which won a landslide election victory last week, ordered an increase in interest rates to 6.25 percent from 6.0 percent on Tuesday.

After a monetary meeting with Bank of England Governor Eddie George, Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown also announced that he was giving the central bank operational independence to set interest rates.
Until now, the Chancellor (finance minister) has set interest rates after taking advice from the Bank of England.
"The enemy of growth and the investment necessary for it is the instability of short periodic bursts of high growth followed by recession," Brown told a news conference.
"We must break from the short-termism of the past and the economic instability that has characterised the British economy, not just in recent years but for most of the century."
